section.content: ADVANCED PULSE and switching lab Studies on RC Low Pass Filter

section.title: Example Frequency Response of RC Low Pass Filter
section.content: Example Frequency Response of RC Low Pass Filter A frequency characterizing a boundary between a passband and a stopband for which the output of the circuit deviates 3 dB from the nominal passband value. This describes the steepness of transition between a stopband and passband measured per decade ( 1 decade = 10 times increase in frequency ).

section.title: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) Drag a function generator and Oscilloscope from the ‘Basic’ Panel. Drag a Resistor and Capacitor.Construct the circuit as below take R = 509 ohm and C= 2 uF.Connect the function generator and oscilloscope as shown below.Connect the ground of the circuit.

section.title: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) For the function generator select sine wave, and Amplitude 2V. In the Function generator, vary the frequency from 0 Hz to 1 KHz in steps of 100 Hz. For each time, note the peak amplitude of the 2 channels in the scope.

section.title: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) Note the PEAKS of CH1 and CH2 from Oscilloscope

section.content: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) Confirm that the circuit indeed is passing lower frequencies and blocking higher frequencies.

section.title: Is there an easier way of doing this ?
section.content: Indeed there is – a way to perform simulations in frequency domain. Is there an easier way of doing this ?

section.title: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) Construct the circuit as before, take R = 500 ohm and C= 2 uF. For the function generator select sine wave, and Amplitude 2V. In the simulation properties, select ‘Frequency Domain Analysis’ and vary the frequency from 0 Hz to 1 KHz in steps of 100 Hz. Click on ‘Run simulation’.

section.title: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )

section.title: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) Click on the ‘Data Analyzer’ to see the results. Plot both the voltages ( Vin and Vout ) wrt Frequency. We can see that the lower frequencies as passed while the higher frequencies are not passed.

section.title: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) Let us now plot the Vout/Vin vs frequency and see the results and find out the ‘3db’ point. Click on ‘Add Equations’ and add the Gain as an equation of Vout/Vin. Run simulation again and click on ‘Data Analyzer’.

section.title: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Experiment Frequency - Response of RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) On the Data Analyzer, plot Gain vs Frequency and Select the Log scale for both X and Y axis to see the bode-plot. Select the full frequency range for the X axis. The ‘3db’ or the turning point can now be mapped in the plot.

section.title: Exploratory : RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Exploratory : RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) Having measured the 3db point, let us try and understand how the 3db point changes with change in Resistor and change in Capacitor.

section.title: Exploratory : RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Exploratory : RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) Construct the circuit as before. In the simulation properties, select ‘Frequency Domain Analysis’ and vary the frequency from 0 Hz to 1 KHz in steps of 100 Hz. Click Advanced and vary the resistance from 0 Ohms to 2500 Ohms. Run simulation.

section.title: Exploratory : RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Exploratory : RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) Click on Data Analyzer to view the change in 3db point. We can see that 3db point is inversely proportional to change in R.

section.title: Exploratory : RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Exploratory : RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) Let us now vary the capacitance. In the simulation properties, select ‘Frequency Domain Analysis’Vary the frequency from 0 Hz to 1 KHz in steps of 100 Hz. Click Advanced and vary the Capacitance from 0 F to 10 uF. Run simulation.

section.title: Exploratory : RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter )
section.content: Exploratory : RC circuit ( Low Pass Filter ) Click on Data Analyzer to view the change in 3db point. We can see that 3db point is inversely proportional to change in C.
